title: Hugh Grant, 59, joins leggy wife Anna Eberstein, 40, at the London premiere of The Irishman
text:
He was once famous for his reluctance to marry, but shunned his bachelor status last year when he tied the knot to his Swedish girlfriend.

And Hugh Grant appeared in great spirits as he attended the UK premiere of The Irishman with his wife Anna Eberstein during the 63rd BFI London Film Festival on Sunday evening.

The screen star, 59, cut a suave figure in a classic black tuxedo as he hit the red carpet with the television producer, 40, who displayed her lean legs in a belted mini-dress.

Date night: Hugh Grant appeared in great spirits as he attended the UK premiere of The Irishman with his wife Anna Eberstein during the 63rd BFI London Film Festival on Sunday

Maintaining his smart appearance, the Notting Hill actor rounded off his outfit with a sleek white shirt and patent brogues.

Mother-of-three Anna, meanwhile, stunned in a thigh-skimming textured ensemble, teamed with a chunky black and gold belt.

Towering over her man in a pair of ankle-strap heels, the blonde beauty styled her tresses in a straight fashion and opted for minimal make-up for a naturally radiant look.

Looking good: The screen star, 59, cut a suave figure in a classic black tuxedo as he hit the red carpet with the television producer, 40, who displayed her lean legs in a belted mini-dress

Dapper: Maintaining his smart appearance, the Notting Hill actor rounded off his outfit with a sleek white shirt and patent brogues

The award-winning actor married his long-term Swedish girlfriend Anna in a low-key ceremony in Chelsea in May 2018.

The couple have been together for seven years, and married for one year, they share three children, John Mungo, who was born in September 2012, and two other children born in 2015 and 2018 - although they have never announced the names.

Father-of-five Hugh also shares two children with his ex Tinglan Hong - Tabitha, seven, and Felix, six.

The Irishman, which hits UK screens on November 8, is the latest gangster film from celebrated director Martin Scorsese.

The film is the ninth feature collaboration between Robert De Niro and filmmaker Martin and their first since Casino in 1995.

In the movie, Robert portrays the role of Sheeran, a mafia hitman and high-ranking Teamster official.

Though the film's genre and cast has led some to expect a gangster thriller in the mould of GoodFellas or Casino, The Irishman is a more reflective, less flashy rumination on morality, violence and American power.
